Comment: *From Bloomberg News reporters Ava Benny-Morrison¬†and¬†Bill Allison:*  Powerful people in business and finance are rushing pitches and stepping up lobbying, catering their appeals to Trump and hiring lawyers with connections to the administration. These defendants with means are spending big for a chance to clear their names, at least in official records if not in public perception. Interviews with about two dozen lawyers and pardon hopefuls, many of whom asked not to be identified discussing plans that weren‚Äôt public, have pulled back the curtain on the clemency process under Trump. Some outlined plans to spend at least tens of thousands of dollars on attorneys, lobbyists and consultants, while others say the costs will reach well north of $1 million to put cases together and get them in front of the White House.  [Read the full story here.](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2025-05-06/trump-s-pardons-have-defendants-spending-1-million-to-get-cases-to-white-house)

Comment: The way our minds work is that we tend to value the positive traits that we have, but tend to not care about them when we don't. For example, if you are a scientists, you would value people being clever a lot, if you are religious, you would value being pious, if you are a professional sportsman, you'd value being athletic. But do dumb people value intelligent people? No, not really. Do unreligious people value being pious? Absolutely not.  So kind people value kindness, but the opposites just don't care about it. People like Trump value themselves on being powerful and that's what they evaluate others on. That's where his fixation on weak/strong is coming from.
